title: 112_hr5875
content: The Act titled "Virgin Islands Visa Waiver Act of 2012" establishes the Virgin Islands Visa Waiver Program. The Virgin Islands Visa Waiver Program under the Immigration and Nationality Act allows nationals of certain countries to enter the United States Virgin Islands for up to 30 days for business or pleasure without meeting certain requirements. The Virgin Islands Visa Waiver Program allows nationals of certain CARICOM countries to enter the US Virgin Islands for up to 30 days without meeting certain requirements, subject to approval by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Virgin Islands Visa Waiver Program allows nationals of certain CARICOM countries to enter the US Virgin Islands for up to 30 days without meeting certain requirements, subject to approval by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Regulations for waivers under this program include waiving rights to review or appeal an immigration officer's determination of admissibility and contesting removal actions, except for specific circumstances. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of State, must promulgate regulations for the Virgin Islands Visa Waiver Act of 2012 within 60 days. These regulations, considered a foreign affairs function, should include a list of CARICOM countries whose nationals may obtain the waiver. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish regulations for the Virgin Islands Visa Waiver Act of 2012 within 60 days. These regulations should include a list of CARICOM countries eligible for the waiver and any additional bonding requirements for nationals posing a risk. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of State, considers various factors when granting or continuing waivers for nationals of any country, including electronic travel authorizations, passport procedures, repatriation, visa refusal rates, overstays, exit systems, and information exchange. The Secretary also monitors nonimmigrant visitor admissions to the United States Virgin Islands under this provision. The Secretary of Homeland Security may suspend the admission of nationals from a country if their presence poses risks to law enforcement or security interests in the United States Virgin Islands or the United States. The Governor of the United States Virgin Islands may request the addition of a country to the visa waiver program, which can be granted by the Secretary of Homeland Security after consultation with other relevant authorities. Regulations may be promulgated regarding the inclusion of the country and any special requirements. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the discretion to impose restrictions on nationals of a country before allowing them to obtain a visa waiver. Amendments are made to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding documentation requirements and the admission of nonimmigrants. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act restrict the stay of aliens admitted to the United States Virgin Islands without a visa to 30 days.
